title: Cuatro (TV channel)
text:
Cuatro (stylized as cuatro°, "Four") is a Spanish <a href="free-to-air">free-to-air</a> <a href="television%20channel">television channel</a> that was launched in November 2005. Owned by <a href="Mediaset%20Espa%C3%B1a">Mediaset España</a>, the Spanish subsidiary of the <a href="italia">italia</a>n <a href="Mediaset">Mediaset</a> group, it is broadcast on TV frequencies licensed to the previous owner <a href="PRISA%20TV">Sogecable</a> in 1990 and previously used by them for the analogue transmission of its <a href="pay-per-view%20channel">pay-per-view channel</a> <a href="Canal%2B%20%28Spanish%20TV%20channel%29">Canal+</a>.
History.
In 2006, Cuatro scored a massive coup by striking a deal with the <a href="Royal%20Spanish%20Football%20Federation">Royal Spanish Football Federation</a> and Spain's <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">national football team</a> allowing it to show all of the team's matches, and it also concluded an agreement with rival channel <a href="La%20Sexta">La Sexta</a> to share the rights to broadcast the games of general interest in the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a>. It snatched this licence from <a href="Televisi%C3%B3n%20Espa%C3%B1ola">TVE</a>, who had held the rights to the national team's matches for years. In 2008, together with satellite platform <a href="Digital%2B">Digital+</a>, owned by the same company, Cuatro secured the rights to broadcast the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008">UEFA Euro 2008</a> championship, scoring the highest ratings in the history of Spanish television (since 1992). The two broadcasters also achieved rights for <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2010 FIFA World Cup</a>. 
On 18 December 2009, <a href="Mediaset">Mediaset</a>, controlling shareholder of <a href="Gestevision%20Telecinco">Gestevision Telecinco</a> and <a href="PRISA">Promotora de Informaciones, S.A</a>, proprietor of <a href="Sogecable">Sogecable</a>, presented an agreement to merge their television channels (<a href="Telecinco">Telecinco</a> and Cuatro). After the merger, Cuatro and its broadcasting license Sogecable separated, and the company - <a href="Sogecuatro">Sogecuatro</a> - was purchased in full by <a href="Gestevision%20Telecinco">Gestevision Telecinco</a>. Along with this act, <a href="PRISA">PRISA</a> bought newly issued shares of <a href="Gestevision%20Telecinco">Gestevision Telecinco</a>, 18% of the equity of this company. This agreement makes <a href="Gestevision%20Telecinco">Gestevision Telecinco</a> in the largest television network in Spain by audience share. In total the group has a total of seven channels, in Terrestrial Television in Spain: <a href="Telecinco">Telecinco</a>, Cuatro, <a href="LaSiete">LaSiete</a>, <a href="Factor%C3%ADaDeFicci%C3%B3n">FactoríaDeFicción</a>, <a href="Boing%20%28Spain%29">Boing</a>, Canal+Dos, <a href="CNN%2B%20%28Spanish%20TV%20network%29">CNN+</a>, Telecinco HD and Canal Club.
The president of the resulting string (which will keep the brands and editorial of both chains) is Alejandro Echevarria, with two CEOs who are Paolo Vasile (Contents) and Giuseppe Tringali (Advertising). <a href="PRISA">PRISA</a> also has two CEOs and holds the vice presidency of the operator.
Prior to this agreement, formalized the entry of <a href="Mediaset">Mediaset</a> in the shareholding of <a href="Digital%20%2B">Digital +</a>, with 22% of the shares.
Programming.
"Cuatro" programming includes "<a href="Supermax">Supermax</a>", "Las mañanas de Cuatro", "<a href="Cuarto%20milenio">Cuarto milenio</a>", "<a href="Tulli%20%28TV%20series%29">Tulli</a>", "<a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a>", "<a href="9-1-1%20%28TV%20series%29">9-1-1</a>", "<a href="SpongeBob%20SquarePants">SpongeBob SquarePants</a>", "<a href="Siren%20%28TV%20series%29">Siren</a>" and "<a href="Castle%20%28TV%20series%29">Castle</a>".
Production.
"Cuatro" currently broadcasts in 16:9 for most of the programs, but in 4:3 for a minority of programming including films and older series.
